hobby.message: Any luck fixing the old typewriter?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: It definitely feels strange out there.
I usually fold origami to unwind.
Couldn5t really focus on my cranes with all the alerts going off.
Paper's hard to come by lately, anyway.
Something's off. System glitches everywhere.
I fold origami models after work. Relaxing, mostly.
Today was hard to concentrate, too much noise.
Even my usual scrap paper had code logs on it.
Not ideal for clean lines or a clear mind.
Yeah, things are... off. Can't ignore the system reversals.
I do origami at home, old office forms mostly.
Tried making a complex tessellation earlier, but the power kept flickering.
Sounded like people coming back who weren't supposed to be around.
Made it hard to focus, but sometimes that helps block out the rest.
Everything's out of sync. Even my hobby feels different now.
I fold origami, intricate patterns from whatever I have — government printouts, sometimes.
Today I tried a dragon design but the paper was a flagged security memo.
The rollback scrambled so much, even my old balcony key worked again.
Ran into a neighbor I'd thought was gone — back like nothing happened.
It all made my folds sloppy, hands a bit shaky.
Somehow, that messiness feels more honest than usual.
Feels like the city’s inside out today.
My thing is origami — precision models, not just cranes, even modular stuff.
I use scrap documents, sometimes the ones the system wants to erase.
Right after the rollback, all my shapes came out oddly sharp — like the city wouldn’t let me make anything soft.
I was folding when I saw a 'ghost' neighbor by the stairwell. She looked just as disoriented.
Usually, origami calms me, but it synced up with all the chaos outside.
It’s strange — watching old routines break down through creased paper.
Sometimes I keep the bad folds, just to remember how it really felt.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Helps a little.
Origami's quiet, simple. No system interference.
Makes waiting in locked corridors tolerable.
Recent system shifts made paper hard to find.
Only fold when sure no one's watching.
It steadies me, mostly.
I fold from whatever I can scavenge — forms, memos.
Sometimes, old documents surface unexpectedly. Useful.
During the system rollback, papers changed hands all over my block.
I had to hide finished models when a ghosted neighbor came by.
Feels riskier lately to leave anything out.
Yes, keeps me focused. Decent distraction.
I like complex models: cranes, tessellations, occasionally insects.
Lately I've had to use recycled audit forms — supplies are tight.
After the BCI rollback, my building’s mailroom was chaos.
Found some rare patterns in discarded council memos last week.
Strange, folding reminders of old routines as rules shift.
Feels like every crease ties past and present together lately.
It really does — origami is my anchor.
Sometimes I fold late, when the system pings quiet down.
Access codes changed after rollback, so I dug out old reports for paper.
You wouldn’t believe the memos people toss when they panic.
Saw someone long-ghosted walk by with a reactivated badge while I folded.
I nearly gave her a folded frog. Thought better of it.
Makes you wonder what gets erased and what reappears.
Models reflect the state of the city right now: jumbled, unpredictable.
Definitely keeps my mind from spiraling. Started as a nervous habit in school.
Now it’s obsessive — I fold leftover compliance letters, council drafts, even warning slips.
Old friends used to tease me for keeping models hidden in vents.
These last few weeks, I’ve found paper with ghosted names, forgotten codes — odd history folded up.
After rollback, I saw neighbors from both sides — favored and vanished — walking the halls again.
Everyone’s tense. Even folding gets you attention if you use the wrong memo.
Sometimes I fold a mistake on purpose, to see if anyone notices.
Origami models are scattered around the block now, like signals, or… markers.
Feels like tiny quiet protests in a city that watches every move.
